OperatorName: City of Lakeland, Water Util. Dept.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
WILLIAMS WATER TREATMENT PLANT

1. Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

The Williams Water Treatment Plant (Williams Plant) is part of Water Utilities a division of the City of Lakeland, Florida. The City of Lakeland requires each site to develop and maintain accident prevention programs and an emergency response plan appropriate to the site.  Each site is also responsible for regulatory compliance issues that apply to the site.  The City of Lakeland Office of Risk Management provides assistance in training for site employees and in budgeting and procurement of safety and training.

2. Description of Facility and Regulated Substance Handled

The Williams Plant is located at 2100 Interstate Drive in the northwest corner of Lakeland, Florida. The plant consists of filtration, clarification, fluoridation and purification processes that treat drinking water for the City of Lakeland. 

The Williams Plant adds chlorine to the filtered water as a purification agent. The chlorination process is located in an enclosed building at the southeast corner of the property, where liquefied chlorine gas is stored in up to twenty-two one-ton containers.  Eight containers are always connected to the chlorination system, and up to fourteen are stored nearby.  The total chlorine inventory in the process at any one time ranges from 16,000 to 44,000 lbs.  This exceeds the 2,500-lb. Risk Management Plan (RMP) threshold quantity.

3. General Accidental Release and Chemical Specific Prevention Steps

The City of Lakeland considers its processes as subject to the Risk Management Process (RMP) regulation and has implemented a RMP program at all facilities which have RMP listed processes.  For RMP compliance purposes, the City of Lakeland is a publicly owned facility and this places the Williams Plant process in the Program 2 level.  The Williams facility implemented the Process Safety Management (PSM) program as required by the RMP Program 2 Preventi

on Program.

The Williams Plant has a program in place to comply with the OSHA Process Safety Management Standard, 29 CFR 1919.119.  The PSM Program was established in 1997 for the chlorine process.  The program includes written operating procedures, preventative maintenance, and employee training to ensure safe operation of the chlorine process. The PSM Program receive full support of plant management and involvement of employees at all levels.

The chlorination process is located in an enclosed building that includes a scrubber capable of filtering up to one ton and process-area chlorine detectors which will set off alarms if a release of chlorine is detected. Chlorine gas flows from the container under vacuum.  Under normal operation, therefore, the chlorine gas is delivered under vacuum through pipe to the chlorine injection points.  If the vacuum is lost, the diaphragm in the vacuum regulator closes, stopping the flow of chlorine gas at the vacuum regulator.  This helps to prevent uncontrolled chlorine releases.

In addition, the written prevention program fulfills the requirements of the OSHA PSM regulation and the EPA RMP rule, and includes but is not limited to:
¿	Formal and on-the-job training, 
¿	Written operating procedures, and 
¿	A process equipment preventive maintenance program.


4. Five Year Accident History

The Williams Plant has had no accidental releases of chlorine in the past five years.

5. Emergency Response Program

As with the Prevention Program, the Williams Plant has an Emergency Response Program in place.  The program complies with 29 CFR 1910.38. The current plans have been coordinated with the Polk County Fire Department and Hazardous Materials Response Team, and the District 7 Local Emergency Planning Committee.  Notification is made locally by dialing 911, and by notifying Florida State Warning Point at (800) 320-0519 or (904) 413-9911.

6. Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Ideas for changes to improve safety are actively sought fr

om employees. Employee meetings that focus on safety issues are held regularly at the facility. Employees are encouraged and trained to recognize hazards and present ideas to eliminate them or to minimize the potential consequences of those hazards. 
Williams plans to address action items resulting from the recent PSM/RMP audit and PHA in order to improve process safety.
